sect1.title: CVS SSH Access (for editors)
sect1.para: For editors, access is slightly more complicated. You first of all need to generate yourself an ssh key-pair. You then need to upload your public key into your ~/.ssh directory on shadowfax. To generate the keys run: ssh-keygen -t dsa When prompted as to where to save them, it's probably best to leave them in .ssh (as id_dsa and id_dsa.pub) unless you already have ssh keys there. When prompted for a passphrase just press enter (unless you want to have to give the phrase every time you perform a cvs operation. Having generated your keys, upload ~/.ssh/id_dsa.pub to shadowfax and move it to ~/.ssh/authorized_keys2 on shadowfax. (Your local copy of id_dsa and id_dsa.pub should remain untouched by this.)

Once you've done this, you need to set environment variables like this: export CVS_RSH=ssh export CVSROOT=:ext:USERNAME@cvs.linuxfromscratch.org:/home/cvsroot But obviously replacing USERNAME with your shadowfax username. I tend to place this into a script which I then source from my .bash_profile or .bashrc script as appropriate. If you only (or mainly) work with the LFS CVS server, this makes life easier as the right variables are always set (and you can override them at the command line temporarily if you need to use another server for some reason).

Once you have this setup, try to checkout the BLFS tree using: cvs checkout BLFS/BOOK If this works, you'll get a nice BLFS/BOOK directory listing and you have your own sandbox!. You also have write access so from now on be extra careful but note that no changes will be made until you use a cvs commit command.
As with anonymous access, you can update your local copy (often called a sandbox) by simply cd'ing into the BLFS directory and running: cvs update
